title-group.article-title: Active vibration control in a cantilever-like structure: a time delay compensation approach

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China

author-notes.corresp: Min-Qiang Shao, State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, 29 Yudao Street, Nanjing 210016, China Email: m.q.shao@nuaa.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The aim of this study is to develop a method of active control based on time delay compensation for the low-order modes of a cantilever-like structure suffering from complex excitations. The time delay is induced by an anti-aliasing filter and a high-order digital low-pass filter, which are introduced to prevent frequency aliasing and observation spillover. However, approaches for time delay processing in active control systems have in the past been model dependent. This paper adopts a velocity feedback control law to increase system damping, and constructs an autoregressive moving average (ARMA) model for eliminating the time delay caused by filters. The ARMA model is model-free and its coefficients are adjusted adaptively according to the outputs of the system. In practical applications, the direct current (DC) excursion induced by the calculation is also considered, and a proper method of DC cancellation is adopted. A wind-tunnel model with rear sting is used as a cantilever-like structure in the experiments. The results reveal that the first mode vibrations of the model are effectively suppressed by this controller when the structure suffers from complex excitations.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: A cantilever-like structure is an infinite-dimensional distributed structure. It is impossible to control or estimate infinite modes, so vibration control in a cantilever-like structure is limited to a finite number of modes. Problems therefore arise in both observation and control spillover because of the mode truncation (Balas, 1978; Meirovitch, 1987). Mei and Mace (2002) applied a feedback wave controller to reduce the resonant response of high-frequency residual modes, and thereby reduce the effects of control spillover.

Another serious problem in discrete control systems is frequency aliasing. Frequency aliasing occurs when the observed signal is transferred from analog to digital form (Weleratna, 2002). An analog anti-aliasing filter is an effective method for preventing frequency aliasing, and a low-pass digital filter can deal with observation spillover. These two kinds of filters are commonly used in signal acquisition and processing (Bilinsky and Mikelsons, 1990; Opperman and Linde, 1991; D’Antonia et al., 1999; Bao et al., 2009). However, filters can affect the stabilization of controlled systems. Liu and Hu (2010) discuss the instability induced by group delay caused by digital filters in a double pendulum control system. Control systems with time delay have been studied by many researchers. Cai and Huang (2003) deal with the input time delay problem by applying an integral transform in controller design. Expanded-dimension methods have also been applied to eliminate the invariant time delay in discrete-time systems (Cai and Huang, 2002). Haraguchi and Hu (2008) have now proposed a state transformation approach to eliminate system time delay. This method does not increase the dimensions of systems, and the computation during the control process is much simpler than for expanded-dimension methods. However, all of the methods mentioned here are model dependent, and cannot be applied to systems with output time delay.

This paper deals with the problems induced by variable output time delay in a control system. The dynamic function of the variable time delay system is resistant to analysis, so an all-pass filter is used to transform the original system into an invariant time delay system. Various approaches have been proposed for designing all-pass filters to satisfy a given group delay specification (Bernhardt, 1980; Jing, 1987; Reddy and Swamy, 1990), but all of these approaches have a common problem, which is that the process of phase compensation inevitably adds another additional time delay. Piskorowski and de Anda (2009) present a new class of delay-compensated parameter-varying low-pass elliptic filters with a transient response of short duration. Compensation for filter-induced time delay has also been studied (Jaskula and Kaszynski, 2004; Lee and Bien, 2004, 2006; Piskorowski and Barcinski, 2008). However, none of the proposed methods eliminates the time delay.

Signal forecasting is an approach for eliminating the invariant time delay. The adaptive forecasting of time series has been studied extensively in recent decades, and applied in many domains, such as economics, electric power systems, neural networks, etc. (Paarmann and Najar, 1995; Paolo and Mattias, 2010; Wong et al., 2010). In order to simplify the calculations and to work with an active vibration control system, a modified forecasting method is proposed here. With this modified signal forecasting, combined with phase compensation, it is possible to eliminate the variable output time delay.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, a control law is proposed for the cantilever-like structure. Section 3 discusses the problems associated with group delay compensation after introducing an anti-aliasing filter and high-order digital low-pass filter; the direct current (DC) excursion induced by the control algorithm is also discussed. In Section 4, a modified forecasting method is proposed to eliminate the invariant time delay, and the identification of the coefficients of the ARMA model is discussed in more detail. Experiments are implemented in Section 5. Finally, this paper ends with some concluding remarks in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Cantilever-like structure and design of a controller
sec.p:
The experiment of the wind tunnel aerodynamic model is a common practice in the aircraft design. Most aircraft models are fixed on rear sting supports. The model and the rear sting make up a cantilever-like structure. Dangerous vibration occurs when the structure suffers strong wind load. The biggest displacement is induced by low frequency resonance modes of the structure. In general, the first mode brings the largest oscillation. Thus, it is appropriate to design controllers aiming at the first modes of the structure. Figure 1 shows a wind-tunnel model fixed on a rear sting, and its vibration control system. It is a cantilever-like structure with control devices. Figure 1.
Wind-tunnel model with rear sting and its control system.

The excitations acting on the structure are unknown. The only information for us is the acceleration as measured by an accelerometer fixed onto the structure. Figure 2 presents an instance of an actual model suffering from strong wind load. The output signal of acceleration includes vibrations of various modes. It would be hard to design a controller to dampen all modes appearing in the output. Fortunately, a low-frequency vibration is obvious, and it has the largest magnitude in the frequency domain, as shown in Figure 2(b). The velocity and displacement during the vibration are mainly attributable to the first mode of the structure. Figure 2.
Acceleration response of an actual model suffering from strong wind load (sample frequency is 2 kHz).

By constructing a finite-element model of the cantilever-like structure, we can convert the continuous model into a system with finite degrees of freedom, and the dynamic model of the system with control can be described as (1)Mz··(t)+Cz·(t)+Kz(t)=P(t)+U(t) where M, C and K are, respectively, the discrete mass, damping and stiffness matrixes; P(t) is the input force on the nodes of the discrete elements, and is unknown; U(t) is the control force; z(t) is the vertical displacement; and M,C,K∈RN×N, P,U,z∈RN×1.

Assume that the structure is a proportionally damped system, and the damping can be described as C=αK+βM, where α,β∈R. Thus, Equation (1) can be decoupled by z(t)=Φq(t), where Φ=[ϕ1ϕ2…ϕN], ϕi is the ith mode, and satisfies ΦTMΦ=I, ΦTCΦ=Λ, ΦTKΦ=Ω. According to Equation (1), one has (2)q··(t)+Λq·(t)+Ωq(t)=p(t)+u(t), whereΛ=diag[2ξiωi](i=1,…,N), ξi is the ith damping ratio; Ω=diag[ωi2](i=1,…,N), ωi2 is the ith natural frequency; q=[q1q2…qN]T is the decoupled coordinate; p=ΦTP; u=ΦTU.

The first mode giving rise to the main vibration of the structure can be separated out from Equation (2), (3a)q··1(t)+2ξ1ω1q·1(t)+ω12q1(t)=p1(t)+u1(t), (3b)~··q(t)+Λ~~·q(t)+Ω~q~(t)=p~(t)+u~(t), where p1(t)=ϕ1TP, u1=ϕ1TU, q~=[q2q3…qN]T, Λ~=diag[2ξiωi] (i=2,…,N), Ω=diag[ωi2] (i=2,…,N), p~=Φ~TP, u~=Φ~TU,Φ~=[ϕ2ϕ3…ϕN].
The displacement response of the structure is (4)z(t)=Φq(t)=[ϕ1Φ~][q1q~T]T=ϕ1q1+Φ~q~.

It is assumed that z⌢(t)=ϕ1q1(t) and z~(t)=Φ~q~(t). Thus, z(t)=z⌢(t)+z~(t), the response z⌢(t) is generated by the first mode of the structure, and z~(t) is the response induced by other modes. Considering the first mode of the vibration is the main part, a controller is designed to respond against z⌢··(t). That is (5)u(t)=-k∫0tz⌢··j(τ)dτ, where z⌢··j∈z⌢·· is a part of the acceleration response on the jth point of the testing model, k is the feedback coefficient and k>0, u(t) is the input of the control force on a point of the structure.

Through solving the integral in Equation (5), the algorithm is transformed into a velocity-like feedback control method as follows: (6)u(t)=-kz⌢·j(t)+c where c=kz⌢·j(0), and z⌢·j(0) is the initial value of velocity response at the testing point, and is undetermined. Thus, the algorithm Equation (5) reduces to a velocity feedback with an undetermined DC signal.

In order to facilitate the evaluation of the effect of the controller, one needs to consider the situation without DC. In this case, Equation (6) becomes a pure velocity feedback control algorithm. As we know, this method produces good stability and is robust for a single-degree-of-freedom (S-DOF) system. However, the cantilever structure here is not an S-DOF system, it is just a single input and single output (SISO) system. Assume that the accelerometer is fixed on the jth node on the structure and the control force acts on the ith node. Thus, the external disturbance and control force can be described as P=[P1P2…PN]T ,U=[0,…,0,Ui,0,…,0]T. By multiplying ϕ1 at the both sides of Equation (3a) and considering the assumption of z⌢(t)=ϕ1q1(t), one obtains (7)z⌢··(t)+2ξ1ω1z⌢·(t)+ω12z⌢(t)=ϕ1p1(t)+ϕ1u1(t) where p1=ϕ1TP and u1=ϕ1TU. There follows, (8)z⌢··(t)+2ξ1ω1z⌢·(t)+ω12z⌢(t)=ϕ1∑k=1Nϕ1kPk(t)+ϕ1ϕ1iUi(t) where ϕ1k is the kth element of ϕ1. Since the accelerometer is fixed on the jth node of the structure, the SISO dynamic function about the first mode is derived as follows (9)z⌢··j(t)+2ξ1ω1z⌢·j(t)+ω12z⌢j(t) =∑k=1Nϕ1jϕ1kPk(t)+ϕ1jϕ1iUi(t) where z⌢j(t) is the displacement of the jth node about the first mode, ϕ1i,ϕ1j are the ith and jth elements of the first mode shape ϕ1.

From Equation (6), the velocity feedback control algorithm without DC can be described as u(t)=-kz⌢·j(t). Let Ui(t)=u(t), and substitute it into Equation (9). The closed-loop dynamic function is then (10)z⌢··j(t)+(2ξ1ω1+ϕ1jϕ1ik)z⌢·j(t)+ω12z⌢j(t)=∑k=1Nϕ1jϕ1kPk(t).

The control algorithm changes the damping of the system. In order to increase the damping of the control system and produce good control performance, the relationship ϕ1jϕ1i>0 should be satisfied. This ensures that the shape values of the vibration mode will retain the same symbol at both the point of action of the control force and the test point of acceleration. The shape of the first mode of the cantilever-like structure is always on the same side of the x-axis, and thus the inequality above is always satisfied. In other words, the control force can operate on any part of the cantilever structure, and the controlled system is always stable.

sec.title: 3. Higher mode signals and DC excursion
3.1. Inutility mode signals
sec.p: The vibration signal z··j(t) includes the response of the structure in the first mode z⌢··j, and higher modes ~··zj (t). Equation (5) refers only to the first mode signal z⌢··j. The existence of ~··zj(t) could therefore have an effect which negates the control and stability of the controlled system. It is necessary to discuss methods for canceling higher mode signals.

There are two problems in signal acquisition. The first is that the signal includes vibrations at various modes, and only one or a part of them are needed. The second is the limitations of sampling frequency, which cannot be set to whatever value we desire, and which may induce frequency aliasing and observation spillover. These two problems can lead to instability in the controlled system. Analog anti-aliasing filters are used extensively in practical projects, and perform well in terms of signal processing. The filter can attenuate part of the high-order mode signal; another important benefit is that it helps to resist observation spillover. However, the filter may give rise to nonlinear phase-frequency characteristics, and induces an undetermined time delay as the signals pass through the filter. Figure 3 shows the characteristics of an anti-aliasing filter in the frequency domain. The pass band of the filter is 0-100 Hz. Figure 3.
Frequency characteristics of an anti-aliasing filter.

The anti-aliasing filter deals with the problems of the frequency aliasing and part of the observation spillover induced by high-order modes. Signals from other modes still exist as disturbances, because part of the higher mode signals is of low enough frequency to get through the pass band of the anti-aliasing filter. These residual mode signals still exist as nonfunctional noise. Thus, a low-pass digital filter should be designed to clear the residual mode signals which are not needed. The parameters of the digital filter are chosen as ωp=0.15, ωs=0.45, Rp=3dB, Rs=60dB, where ωp, ωs are the normal cutoff frequency of the pass band and normal start frequency of the stop band, Rp is the maximum ripple of the pass band, and Rs is the minimum attenuation of the stop band. The cutoff frequency of the pass band and the start frequency of the stop band are 15 Hz and 45 Hz, respectively, when the sample frequency is 200 Hz. The frequency domain characteristics of the digital filter are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Frequency characteristics of the digital low-pass filter.

As shown in Figures 3 and 4, the phase has nonlinear characteristics with respect to frequency. These characteristics induce variable time delays. The group time delay is (11)τg=-dϕdω where ϕ is the phase of the filters and is a function of frequency ω.

It is hard to compensate for variable delays in time domain. Using Equation (11), a linear relationship should be established between phase and frequency in order to ensure invariable group delay. However, the combination of filters has nonlinear phase characteristics with respect to frequency, so phase compensation is necessary. The digital all-pass filter has a function allowing adjustment of the phase of the signal, and this is helpful as we obtain an invariable time delay system.

The general form of the all-pass filter is described by (12)Hapf(z)=N(z)D(z)=∑n=0NaaN-nz-n∑n=0Naanz-n where Na is the order of the all-pass filter, a0=1 and ai(i=1…N) is the constant coefficients of the filter.
Substituting z=ejω into Equation (12) yields (13)Hapf(ejω)=e-jω∑n=0Nanejωn∑n=0Nane-jωn where ω=2πf,f is the frequency, and f∈[0,fs/2], fs is the system sample frequency.

The all-pass filter is designed for eliminating nonlinear phase characteristic induced by the anti-aliasing filter and the digital low-pass filter. As shown in Figure 5, when the signal x(t) passes through the anti-aliasing filter, the low-pass filter and all-pass filter, the phase of the output y(t) can be described as follows: (14)ϕy=ϕx+ϕAAF+ϕLPF+ϕAPF where ϕx is the phase of signal x at time t; ϕAAF, ϕLPF and ϕAPF are the phase variation induced by anti-aliasing filter, low-pass filter and all-pass filter, respectively. Since the ideal status is ϕy=ϕx, the ideal phase characteristic of all-pass filter is (15)ϕAPF*=-(ϕAAF+ϕLPF) where ϕAAF+ϕLPF is the phase of the combination of the anti-aliasing and the low-pass filter. Thus, the ideal phase characteristics of the filter are equal to the negative of the combination of the anti-aliasing and the digital low-pass filter. Figure 5.
Signal flow of x(t).

The combination of phase characteristic and the result of phase compensation of all-pass filter are shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. The normalized frequency is used in the two figures, actual frequencies are obtained by multiplying by fs/2, where fs is the sample frequency of the system. Figure 6.
Phase characteristic of the combination of the anti-aliasing and the low-pass filter against frequency.
Figure 7.
Phase compensation result of the all-pass filter (N=30).

When the signal passes through the all-pass filter, an invariable time delay is generated as (16)τa=Na-τ¯d where Na is the order of the all-pass filter, τ¯d=1M∑k=0M-1τd(k), τd(k) is the group delay of an all-pass filter.

sec.title: 3.2. Cancellation of DC excursion
sec.p: Given the control algorithm of Equation (6), the integral operation induces DC excursion. This result is calculated from Equation (5), of which the output is z⌢··j with no DC excursion. If we consider a case in which the output z⌢··j does include DC excursion, then substitute it into Equation (5), the control algorithm yields an unstable form u(t)=-kz⌢·j(t)+c1t+c2. Thus, DC cancellation is necessary to ensure the stability of the control algorithm.

A simple DC cancellation method is proposed, which includes an important part as an average solver. The average of a discrete time series data with invariable length is defined as x¯(k)=1N∑i=0N-1x(k-i); the difference of the average yields (17)x¯(k)-x¯(k-1)=1N(x(k)-x(k-N)) where x(k) is the data of discrete time series, N is the length of data, k means the current position in the series.
Assume that x(k-n)=x(k)z-n, where z-1 is the discrete operator. Substituting it into Equation (17) yields (18)x¯(k)=H¯1(z-1)x(k) where H¯1(z-1)=1N1-z-N1-z-1 is a transfer function.

By removing the average part from series x and substituting it into Equation (18), a new series without DC excursion is derived (19)x~(k)=x(k)-x¯(k)=H1(z-1)x(k) where H1(z-1)=1NN-1-Nz-1+z-N1-z-1, x~(k) is the series without DC excursion.

An order-one DC eliminator is defined as in Equation (19), and its magnitude and phase characteristics are presented in Figure 8 against frequencies of the transfer function. It shows the DC eliminator is stable at all frequencies, and the large attenuation occurs at zero frequency. The variability of phase is between 0° and 90°, the range is smaller than high-pass filters. But there are too many ripples in the magnitude and phase curves. Let H¯2(z-1)=H¯12(z-1), the transfer function of the order two DC eliminator yields (20)H2(z-1)=1-H¯2(z-1)=1N2N2-1-2N2z-1+N2z-2+2z-N-z-2N1-2z-1+z-2. Figure 8.
Magnitude and phase of the order-one DC eliminator against frequency.

Figure 9 presents the magnitude and phase of the order-two DC eliminator against frequencies with different length N. The ripples of magnitude and phase curves attenuate much faster than with the order-one eliminator. The only fault is that the maximum ripple magnitude is larger than that of the order-one eliminator over the same N. To prevent this being a problem, the frequency of the maximum ripple should be smaller than the effective frequency of the system. Figure 9.
Magnitude and phase of the order-two DC eliminator against frequency.

sec.title: 4.1. Forecast of a time series model
sec.p: An invariant time delay is generated when the signal passes through the anti-aliasing filter, digital low-pass filter and phase compensator. The phase characteristics of the order-two DC eliminator show phase variation close to zero at the relevant frequencies. Thus, the DC eliminator does not introduce a time delay to be considered. The whole normalized time delay of the system is τa, from Equation (16). Thus, the sample delay is (21)Nd=[τa]int where [τa]int rounds τa to the nearest integers.

The following autoregressive moving average (ARMA) model is introduced to describe the discrete delay system using the sample delay, (22)x∧(k-Nd)=∑i=1Ndaix∧(k-Nd-i) +∑i=1Mdbix(k-2Nd-i)+w(k) where x∧(k-Nd) is the estimation of x(k-Nd), w(k) is the error of estimation, ai,bi are coefficients, and Nd, Md are constant positive integers.
Define a new set of variables as xk-Nd=[x∧(k-Nd-1),…x∧(k-2Nd),x(k-2Nd-1), …x(k-2Nd-Md)]T
By substituting these into Equation (22), one yields (23)x∧(k-Nd)=axk-Nd+w(k) where a=[a1,…,aNd,b1,…,bMd].
Equation (23) is a classical average recursive (AR) model, so the coefficients of the model can be found using the stochastic approximation (SA) method.

From the SA method, the estimate of the coefficient a is described as (24)a∧k=a∧k-1+ρkxk(y(k)-a∧k-1xk-Nd) where a∧k-1 is the last estimate of a, y(k)=x(k-Nd) is the current output of system, ρk is a scalar quantity that satisfies the following Dvoretzky conditions (25a)limk→∞ρk=0, (25b)limk→∞∑i=1kρi=0, (25c)limk→∞∑i=1kρi2<∞.
A simple form of ρk satisfying the above conditions is (26)ρk=ρ0k where ρ0 is a positive constant.
Thus, the estimation of x(k) without delay can be described as (27)x∧(k)=a∧kxk where xk=[x∧(k-1),…x∧(k-Nd+1),x(k-Nd),…x(k-Nd-Md)]T.

sec.title: 4.2. Simulation
sec.p:
Assume a discrete time series y(k) with invariant time delay. The original signal sequence without delay is x(k). Given the delay sample Nd, one has y(k)=x(k-Nd). The structure of the delay compensation is shown in Figure 10. The time delay generator in the figure is used for simulating the delay induced by all kinds of filters, phase compensator and devices in system. Figure 10.
The structure of time delay compensation (Ex is the estimation of x, y is the signal with time delay).

The parameters of the ARMA model are settled as Md=Nd=50. From Equations (23), (24), (26) and Figure 10, the effects of estimation using this model on different kinds of time delay series are shown in Figures 11–13, respectively. The characteristics of these series are come from the output signal of the vibrant systems in actual application. Figure 11.
The result of forecasting against the stable harmonic signal (x(t)=sin(20π·t), ρ0=1).
Figure 12.
The result of forecasting against the composite of stable harmonic signals (x(t)=sin(10π·t)+sin(20π·t)+0.5sin(30π·t),ρ0=0.5).
Figure 13.
The result of forecasting against resultant signals (x(t)=sin(20π·t)·sin(π·t),ρ0=5).

sec.title: 5. Experimental study
sec.p:
Experiments were designed to validate the theoretical predictions of vibration control in a wind-tunnel model with real sting. The actual experimental model and relative devices are shown in Figure 14. The accelerometer is fixed in the head of the model. It acquires the output response of the model vibration, and the acceleration signal is transformed from a charge into a voltage signal by a constant current source. The anti-aliasing filter is a pre-signal processing device, whose characteristics have been explained above. The analog signal is transformed into discrete data by a data acquisition card named DAQ2206 which is installed in the IPC (Industrial Personal Computer). The control algorithm and the rest of the signal processing can now be performed by the IPC, and the control signal is transformed from digital to analog form by the DAQ card. The control actuator is fixed inside the model, and driven by the outputs of the DAQ card after amplification by power amplifier. An electromagnetic actuator is mounted under the model. It is driven by harmonic and random signals for simulating the situation in a wind tunnel. The combination of the two kinds of excitations can induce complex responses, similar to the responses of the wind tunnel model under strong wind conditions. Figure 14.
Experimental model and devices.

The signal flow of the control system is shown in Figure 15. The controller is designed as in Equation (5). The characteristics of the anti-aliasing and digital low-pass filters are described in Figures 3 and 4, respectively. After phase compensation, the delayed time induced by the filters and phase compensation is 250 ms. And the time delay induced by hardware devices is smaller than a sample time 5 ms, the sample frequency here is 200 Hz. Figure 15.
Signal flow of the control system.

The displacement responses of the model under control are illustrated in Figure 16, with the response measured by an accelerometer. The displacement in the figure is calculated from acceleration. In order to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method and show that it is different from other control methods, the experiments regarding pure velocity feedback control without filters and forecasting processing are implemented. The results are illustrated in Figure 17. It shows that the responses of the system do not converge. Figure 16.
The displacement responses of the testing point of the model under complex excitations (the response without control at the first 2 seconds, k is the gain of the controller, and (a) k = 100, (b) k = 160).
Figure 17.
Displacement response of the model under pure velocity feedback control.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper we have presented an application of signal forecasting to damping vibration in a cantilever-like structure, a system with output time delay. Combined with phase compensation, the method presented could process variable time delay systems. A DC cancelation algorithm allows the controller to maintain stability. A control algorithm is designed based on acceleration output and adapted to the first mode of the structure, which generates the structure's main displacement response. With effective processing of system outputs, a physical controller applying this algorithm performed successfully in experiments using a wind tunnel model subject to complex excitation including harmonic and random elements. Experimental results illustrate that up to 90% of the displacement response can be eliminated with control, and show that it is more effective than the pure velocity feedback method.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the NSF of China under grant 10825207.
